pTitle: BLU R1 HD - 16 GB - Black - Prime Exclusive - with Lockscreen Offers & Ads
rText:
The phone is really nice for the price. The only problem I had that was a hassle was the SD Card when inserted ask to be used as Internal or External Storage, I chose internal and this let the phone work but some apps would not work and others ran very slow. After not being able to use the SD Card for storing music through an app so I looked at it and the phone when using the SD Card as internal storage corrupts the SD Card messing up the partitions. To fix this take the SD Card out put it into a card reader on your PC and use a Disk Partition app and redo the partitions with default options and reformat it with default options. You can then put it back into the phone and this time select to use it as external storage. It may want to reformat the SD card again that is fine.

After doing this the apps the did not work now worked, apps that was slow open fast and the SD card is now seen by all programs and able to be used.
rTitle: The phone is really nice for the price

pTitle: BLU Studio X8 HD - 5.0" GSM Unlocked Smartphone -White
rText:
DO NOT BUY THIS PHONE. It is pre-loaded with adware that cannot be removed: banner ads as well as full-screen ads. A factory reset revealed that the adware was indeed pre-installed (before the reset, I had only installed two extremely reputable apps, so I was certainly not the source of the adware).

Some Googling showed that others have had the same experience with the same pre-installed adware. One Amazon review from three months ago referencing the adware even has a response from BLU: acting as if they didn't know the adware -- that took me less than 10 minutes to track down -- came installed on phones they themselves sell. Absolutely disgusting.

I have gone ahead and changed all passwords for all accounts accessed through this phone: if there's adware, spyware is not an unrealistic concern. Indeed an internet search shows this is a very real worry -- I have not investigated for myself, but better safe than sorry. If you want peace of mind after buying this phone, that's what you're going to have to do. Not a very positive aspect of the purchasing experience.

The touchscreen is not the most responsive. This is extremely evident if you use handwriting input. Clicks are often interpreted as drags.
rTitle: Absolutely disgusting. I have gone ahead and changed all passwords ...

rText:
This is a very nice phone for the money.
Further, this is a very nice phone.
You get a little more bezel than you would for $300 to $500 more... but the only thing I wanted in a phone (and didn't get) was wireless charging.
No bloatware.
Think about it, how much would you pay to not have that crap on your phone?
I've got this and an eyephone seven s (work phone) and this blows the doors off that piece of fruit.
Buy it if you need a phone. You won't be sorry.

rText: The Moto G5 plus phone has a speaker problem that Lenovo has not addressed with appropriate firmware update. I bought a Moto G4 plus for my wife and both of us are happy with it, therefore I had high expectations for the new G5 plus I recently purchased. Unfortunately the Moto G5 plus has issues with call volume. It is very difficult to hear phone conversations. Speaker mode doesn't help either. The speaker volume seems fine with all media except phone calls . On the Moto Lenovo users web forum multiple people have complained of this issue and Lenovo has not issued a satisfactory response.
rTitle: Moto G5 plus has speaker problem

pDescr:
Offer Type:Prime Exclusive - With Offers & Ads  |  Size:32 GB Storage + 2 GB RAM  |  Color:Lunar Gray
Meet the new, carrier-friendly Moto G PLUS. This phone is all about performance you won’t outgrow. It takes stunning photos thanks to an advanced 12 MP camera and along with an all-day battery, gets up to 6 hours of power in just 15 minutes of TurboPower. It also comes in a streamlined design that fits nicely in your pocket and also comes with a fingerprint scanner/sensor.
pTitle: Moto G Plus (5th Generation) - Lunar Gray - 32 GB - Unlocked - Prime Exclusive - with Lockscreen Offers & Ads
rText:
I have held off on reviewing this phone until the honeymoon period was over and it lost its new phone feel.

I will start off by saying, I have the Prime version and have not found the ads to be annoying or overly intrusive. With that out of the way,...

This phone has an amazing boot animation with shows off the color depth and range of the screen. Setting it up was easy, like you would expect and without any hiccups. I was coming from a Moto X Pure so I had some expectation of being under-whelmed by the phone. However, I must say I have been pleased with the performance of the SOC and the UI is very intuitive. The Moto Gestures are still in the UI, "chop for flashlight, twist for camera" and the "Moto Display" is still there. However, coming from the X Pure, this phone lacks the IR sensors to detect a hand wave over the screen, so your actually have to move the phone in order to get the Moto Display to come on.

At first I was a little disappointed with the 5.2" screen, because I felt I was losing some screen real estate coming from the X Pure. However, there is the nifty One Button Navigation which takes away the on screen navigation keys and allows you to do everything with the finger print scanner. So, it felt like I gained most of that 0.5" back, when I turned on the One Button Nav. Once you get used to using the One Button features and gestures, going back to on screen buttons feels very awkward and cumbersome.

The one almost complaint I would have about the phone, is that you have to be very particular when selecting an SD card if you want the phone to use it as internal memory. I thought I had picked out a card which was fast enough, however I kept getting various application errors and would sometimes have issues with the devices I had Bluetooth connections with.

This phone would have to be one of the best mid-range devices on the market at the moment. And for the price, with or with out the Prime ads, it is a great value for the money.

One thing the buyer should be aware of, is that Moto/Lenovo seems to have gotten behind on their security patches and software updates. So if this is important for you, it might be something to consider. The unit I have, is still running Android 7.0, the kernel version is from Feb 6, 2017 and the Security Patch is from January 1, 2017

**UPDATE** Upon rereading my review, I realized I had not mentioned anything about the camera quality. I have to say the camera takes really good pictures, especially for this price point. While it does have the same sensor as another "flagship" phone, do not expect it to take flagship level pictures. However, both of the cameras do really well in regards to pictures.

rText: I had a company iPhone for five years and recently quit and needed to get my own phone. After initially considering the $700 or so iPhone from Verizon, and I heard the new one in a few months will be around $900, I decided to do some research. Not only did I decide on a different wireless company but also decided on the Moto G Plus and I couldn't be happier on both counts. The Moto screen is larger than the iPhone 6s and seems to be perfect for me... any larger and it would be too big. I love the fingerprint unlock and downloading apps without connecting a cable to my computer and iTunes is great. The iPhone 6s cannot do all of that. It has other great features that I like, such as putting the phone face down if you don't want to be disturbed or picking it up to change it from ringing to vibrate or shaking it twice to turn the flashlight on or off, and many more. Finding out about features like that was easy since there is a Moto app on the phone that walks you through helpful features. If the iPhone did these thingsI never knew for five years since Apple doesn't communicate those things. Bottom line is I like the Moto much better and save hundreds of dollars also. Why the iPhone costs four times much is beyond me. And for those interested, I'm using Republic Wireless. The coverage has been great so far and I got the $20 a month 1 GB service. There are less and more expensive plans available depending on data use.
rTitle: I love the Moto G Plus 5th generation compared to the iPhone I had

pTitle: Moto G Plus (5th Generation) - Lunar Gray - 32 GB - Unlocked - Prime Exclusive - with Lockscreen Offers & Ads
rText: This phone has one glaring problem. It randomly and often disconnects from the cellular carrier. The sim card disappears from the phone once every hour or so since I put the card from AT&T in it on Sunday. When it works as a cellphone calls are generally clear and not garbled. That could be the fault of AT&T being better than Verizon. The only way to restore service is to shut down the phone and restart it. This is more than an inconvenience. It is unacceptable! If I don't receive an answer and a permanent solution from Motorola, a Lenovo company, I will return this cellular catastrophe for a full refund.
rTitle: Goodbye Moto! Don't buy this cellular catastrophe

pTitle: Figo Virtue PRO 4.0 - Unlocked Dual Sim Smartphone/Mediatek 6580 Quad Core 1.0 GHz/1GB RAM/8GB memory/Android 6 /5 MP Main Camera & 2 MP Camera with LED flash/4.0" IPS Display/(Black) -1 Year Warranty
rText:
Think of this as a basic, minimalist, get the job done but without too many frills, in some sense potentially even disposable phone. Unfortunately, some people will buy this phone (for around 50 dollars) and expect to somehow get a Galaxy S8, and frankly those folks are going to be disappointed. HOWEVER, for what it is supposed to be, it’s great. This is most definitely a product for a specific kind of cell phone user. If you happen to that kind of user, you will really like it.
It comes with a somewhat “conservative” quad core processor, so don’t expect miracles with respect to processing power, but most games and limited multi-tasking will be OK. The 8 GB of built-in storage is decidedly on the lightweight side, and that actually only gives you about 4 GB for your own stuff out of the box, but the ability to add an SD Card and have Android “adopt” it to be internal storage makes up for that. It accepted an additional 32 GB for me with no complaints. Storage problems solved.
An earlier version of this device sort of, maybe, kind of, perhaps barely had enough RAM to run Android Lollipop, and it would on occasion limp along noticeably while it did. The Virtue Pro comes with 1 GB of RAM, which is more than enough to do a very acceptable job of running its fairly lean Android Marshmallow build, along with a concurrent app or two, even if it may not set the world on fire while doing so.
Dual SIM capability almost seems like gilding the lily on a device like this, but it is in there. Actually, it is difficult to find ANY cell phone these days that doesn’t support dual SIMs. Bluetooth works rather well, but USB OTG and screen casting are not going to be found. Battery life is OK, although maybe not spectacular. If you are going to be talking non-stop all day long and expect that to happen on a single charge, this may not be the phone for you. It does charge quickly enough that you could top it off without too much trouble. It is NOT 4G LTE, but it DOES support the lower end of 4G speeds with HSPA+ (think 3G on steroids). If you’re going to use it with Netflix or any other streaming service, perhaps better to do it over a Wi-Fi connection, although I was pleasantly surprised at how well HSPA+ can actually do in a pinch.
The tiny screen has decent resolution and good picture quality as long as you aren’t expecting full HD. The tiny control buttons could be a bother if, like me, you have LARGE hands. The screen also seems to be a really effective fingerprint dirt and smudge magnet, so it might require more frequent cleaning. The camera functionality is good for casual photos and selfies if you are so inclined. Sound quality on voice calls is decent as well. It doesn’t have every feature under the sun, but the features it does have work the way they should.
It fits in your pocket with room to spare. The shell is made of some high impact plastic, which makes it incredibly light, and makes the TPU case most phones come with these days pretty much irrelevant. People who say it almost feels like a toy in their hands are quite correct. It comes with a (flexible plastic variety) screen protector pre-installed, although I would like to see tempered glass as an option since I prefer the tactile sensation of real glass on a touch screen. Everything you need is in the box. Just add a SIM Card (and an SD Card for extra storage) and you’re good to go.
It is a good music device for a long run, bike ride, or a trip to the gym. It’s amazingly light, and mine pairs flawlessly with my Bluetooth headset. It would be PERFECT to give to younger children for their first phone, not only because they have smaller hands, but because, well, things happen with kids and cell phones. Aside from losing them with regularity, kids sometimes accidentally manage to feed their first cell phone to their dog, or drop it in a swimming pool. I have personally known these things (and more) to happen. It’s probably better if it happens with a 50 dollar phone rather than a 500 dollar phone.
Heck, you could just keep one of these as a spare in case your uber-priced flagship phone decides to catch fire one day and you need a phone while waiting for the replacement. The Virtue Pro is a good phone, it is reasonably priced, and at the possible risk of contradicting the cell phone purists, it is a FUN kind of device.

You have the power to push culture forward. That’s why Honor created a phone for you - the new Honor 8. It’s the smartphone that opens your eyes to a world of possibilities. The innovative bionic 12MP dual lenses of the Honor 8 are your eyes to the world. One lens allows for rich color and the other lens is monochrome to give you more light and increased sharpness. Together they help you capture crisper, more detailed photos day and night. Plus, the fusion focus technology of laser, depth, and contrast helps you take the best pictures-even under the most challenging conditions. The premium, slick body of the Honor 8 is made with heavy dual glass-front and back. Its aluminum alloy, 15-layer craftsmanship, and light-catching glass finish makes you stand out from the crowd. Supported by Smart Power 4.0, the Honor 8 has maximum long-lasting battery life that lasts all day and fast-charging technology to reach 47% power in just 30 minutes. So when you’re out there changing the world, Honor 8 has you covered-with up to 10 hours of nonstop video playback and a speedy recharge. The Honor 8: Beautiful design, top-flight specs, game-changing camera technology, and maximum power. Honor 8 - Eyes to the World.

If I compare it with s8 then its faster in browsing, fingerprint scanning, quick and slik UI experience, better and simple keyboard and lot more except camera..

Thanks Huawei for making true smartphone..

pDescr:
Size:32 GB  |  Offer Type:Phone Only  |  Color:Sapphire Blue
You have the power to push culture forward. That’s why Honor created a phone for you - the new Honor 8. It’s the smartphone that opens your eyes to a world of possibilities. The innovative bionic 12MP dual lenses of the Honor 8 are your eyes to the world. One lens allows for rich color and the other lens is monochrome to give you more light and increased sharpness. Together they help you capture crisper, more detailed photos day and night. Plus, the fusion focus technology of laser, depth, and contrast helps you take the best pictures-even under the most challenging conditions. The premium, slick body of the Honor 8 is made with heavy dual glass-front and back. Its aluminum alloy, 15-layer craftsmanship, and light-catching glass finish makes you stand out from the crowd. Supported by Smart Power 4.0, the Honor 8 has maximum long-lasting battery life that lasts all day and fast-charging technology to reach 47% power in just 30 minutes. So when you’re out there changing the world, Honor 8 has you covered-with up to 10 hours of nonstop video playback and a speedy recharge. The Honor 8: Beautiful design, top-flight specs, game-changing camera technology, and maximum power. Honor 8 - Eyes to the World.
pTitle: Huawei Honor 8 Unlocked Smartphone 32 GB Dual Camera - US Warranty (Sapphire Blue)
rText:
Great value for the specs. Bought my Honor 8 64gb around February 2017.

Camera quality is moderate under weird lighting conditions, but for the majority of the shooting a normal person would do, it holds up. The front camera quality is above average, notice less problems there.

Almost missing a star since I've noticed some software glitches using Spotify on bluetooth and wifi connections. Sometimes the app won't 'see' devices (I have two Chromecast Audios and a regular Chromecast) to connect to over wifi or it'll randomly drop bluetooth connections to my car's stereo / have trouble connecting after I turn my car off and then back on again.

I only bought this phone because it comes with insane levels of customization for the UI. Being able to choose between an iPhone style app layout or Android stock or using your own launcher is pretty great.

This is the phone of choice for somebody who wants a moderately priced flagship killer. This phone comes with some amazing capabilities due to the EMUI OS. Software glitches aside, I'm not looking at replacing this phone at all for the foreseeable future. Usually rebooting the app or the phone itself resolves any software problem.

pTitle: Huawei Honor 8 Unlocked Smartphone 32 GB Dual Camera - US Warranty (Sapphire Blue)
rText: I was a bit skeptical at first because I've never heard of the brand Hauwei. I decided to give it a try after reading other positive reviews. For the price, this is a very nice phone. Build quality is good and the metal edges and glass back make the phone look and feel more premium. It performs well and has good battery life. The screen is a good size and the picture is sharp. The camera on this phone is impressive. Pictures look sharp and It works well in low light conditions, which I wasn't expecting. Having a microSD card slot is convenient for expanding storage. I'm very happy with this phone and would buy another Hauwei phone in the future.

pTitle: ASUS ZenFone 3 MAX ZC520TL Smartphone, 5.2-inch, 16GB (Glacier Silver)
rText:
I've loved ASUS motherboards and video cards for the past decade. I really thought this phone was going to be great, but it is extraordinary garbage. For brevity..

Do you want your phone to freeze on you? Get the ZenFone 3
Do you want to take a picture and it wait 22 seconds after hitting the shutter button to have it register?? Get the ZenFone 3
Do you want to delete every app in your phone hoping to free up enough memory and still be burning 70% with nothing running? Get the f*#)@&# ZenFone 3

I flashed this phone and followed a litany of suggestions from tech boards across the internet, trying to boost its speed. I literally deleted every non essential app in the phone, restricted the usage of apps I couldn't delete, set a generic background and shut off wifi/bluetooth/etc and this phone was still showing 70% memory usage.. Perhaps I received a defective phone, but I would recommend an iphone 4 over this one.

rText: Super Phone, Camera, Google device. No problems for me at 2 months now. It is always in my pocket, my hand, or charger. Couple recent photos.I got it at a discount as damaged box, but I really didn't see any damage and all parts were present and new as well as perfect working order.

pDescr:
Size:MAX  |  Offer Type:2GB RAM/16GB Storage

pTitle: ASUS ZenFone 3 MAX ZC520TL Smartphone, 5.2-inch, 16GB (Glacier Silver)
rText:
I started having trouble with it from the very beginning. The battery really dies overnight. I charge it on the morning and by midday it all ready at 25%. I would understand that if I where using it all the time, but really hate being on the phone all the time and basically use it for calls.

The volume turns on or off by itself, as if the buttons were stuck or something. I noticed that when that happens the turn off button wouldn't work so the screen would stay on. First time it happened I reset it and then it wouldn't turn on again. I plug it to the charger and after some time it turn itself on.

The some other stuff kept happening. It world reset by itself and when it turned on my apps where all rearranged. Some apps kept having trouble and get stuck with out working.

Those problems I would expect from a year old phone, but not a week old.

Over all, it sucks! I have an Asus Republic of Gamers and it works awesome! But maybe Asus should stick to computers.

The only good about this phone is the camera, but even that kept freezing.

Good luck new buyers! ;)
rTitle: A good camera but a very bad cell phone

pTitle: ASUS ZenFone 3 MAX ZC520TL Smartphone, 5.2-inch, 16GB (Glacier Silver)
rText:
I purchased this phone to replace an Asus ZE551ML "Makers' Model" cell phone that I RAN OVER TWICE with my son's Honda Accord. It still works! except the gorilla glass 3 screen shattered. I plan to replace that screen for $20, since the LCD digitizer still works perfectly (ZERO dead pixels) and use it for a backup phone. But this gave me a perfect excuse to upgrade to the newest Zenphone ZS570KL.. With 4gb ram, my old phone would boot up faster than any of my coworkers I-crap, Samsung or LG phones. The new model features 6gb, and I expect that it will be even faster. The old phone would stream effortlessly any video from YouTube, Netflix, real time tv on the Xfinity app and Big10toGo app. With the increased specs, I am confident that this phone will outperform the old one. And please remember to compare apples to apples. The ZS570KL is the stripped down version of Asus flagship cell phone, but still will outperform any of the "other guys" flagship phones for $400-$500 less. And did I mention that I ran the previous phone over with a car TWICE and it STILL WORKED?
Asus customer service is well known across the IT industry. I did have the previous phone sent to Asus for a battery issue, and within 14 days, I received my phone back with a new battery AT NO COST. Shipping or otherwise. If YOU damage a product, do not expect Asus to replace it at no charge (although I personally know of a few cases that they have...). Anyone who deals in electronics or computer parts knows that Asus sets the industry standard in both qualityand customer care. Don't believe me? Call any computer repair or retailer, or even somewhere like NewEggs customer service and ask. The only negative responses on here were for the Zenfone 2 Laser cell phone, which did have issues. So just stay away from that model, and you will be doing yourself a solid.
rTitle: But this gave me a perfect excuse to upgrade to the newest Zenphone ZS570KL

rText:
I upgraded to a 6 plus because I wanted a larger screen but this phone has been a bit wonky since I got it. The home button and the lightning connector can be a bit temperamental, every once in a while the phone will just lock up for no reason, and just recently the headset jack went weird on me! There is no sound on the phone anymore unless you use the headphones. The phone will randomly shut itself off and restart (usually once or twice a week).

I would say unless you are desperate for an iphone or buying it for someone who breaks phones easily you should save your money. If you're gonna have to replace it in 6 months you may as well just spring for a brand new one and save yourself the hassles!

pTitle: Apple iPhone 6 Plus 16GB Factory Unlocked GSM 4G LTE Smartphone, Space Gray (Certified Refurbished)
rText: When I first recieved the phone everything was fine, no scratched no cracks looking as brand new as can be. I went along and connected my service to this phone and it did connect perfectly no issues there. The problems start 3 days after connecting this phone, for one the camera shutter sound can't be turned off, second my phone had a bit of a glitch when it came to recording there was always lagging, third, on the fourth day after connecting it it began to freeze up for a couple seconds at a times, but as a couple days went by it would freeze minutes at a time to a point where the screen would go white or the screen would take on its mind of its own. It started to freeze up multiple times through out the day until I couldnt risk it anymore because it began typing in the text messages and selecting photos to send out which OBVIOUSLY nobody wants to deal with, I printed a return label restarted my phone to delete all of my information which took 2 hours because it was basically a war with the phone to access it and actually be in control of the screen. Finally its in the return box, with all of my information deleted and of course still glitching. Long story short im going to the apple store and treating mysef to the iphone 7 IDC how much more it will cost me at least I know for a fact I will be satisfied. P.S this is definitely a "too good to be true" deal.

rText:
DO NOT BUY
This item is being sold as new when it's obviously refurbished.
1: Original product packaging was obviously opened and poorly resealed.
2. No product manual present in box.
3. Inside the phone were signs of handling; stickers partially peeled off, fingerprints.
4. ITEM IS DEFECTIVE; The touchscreen worked less than 50% of the time, and the battery life is atrociously short, and I can't tell if it's because the battery isn't new or if there's so much bloatware running in the background that it just consumes the battery.
5. OTHER DEFECT: the screen dimmer malfunctioned and would not maintain the brightness levels set by the user.

This is the second Galaxy S4 I've owned, so I knew what to expect with this product, and it simply did not meet expectations.
rTitle: DO NOT BUY - REFURBISHED, NOT NEW. DEFECTIVE

rText: I bought this telephone and received it March 24, 2017 for someone and gave them on April 30, 2017 for a birthday present. I took it back for a couple days to evaluate it and found that I could power it on but it won't stay on. I bought a new battery and it did the same thing. This is the second Galalaxy S-4 that I've purchased in four months and not happy with. The last one was a Christmas present and by March it started directing all calls to voicemail without the phone ringing. After you notice that you have not received any calls for a few hours and check it out, you have to power the phone on and off to correct the problem temporarily. I just feel like the Samsung S-4s are not good phones.

The revolutionary Galaxy S5 from Verizon is ALSO unlocked for all GSM carriers like AT&T, T-Mobile, etc. This smartphone is 4G LTE capable and offers the most excellent viewing experience a smartphone can offer. Its FHD Super AMOLED display is brighter with more clarity.
pTitle: Samsung SM-G900V - Galaxy S5 - 16GB Android Smartphone Verizon - Black (Certified Refurbished)
rText:
After several months of use, I can say I really love this phone! Came without all the stuff (stupid games, etc) that take up memory. Easy to operate, clear voice on both speaker for ear & other. Takes great pictures (for what it is) with a zoom function. And, it has reception in many places which are sketchy for it.

Battery life has been very good and I usually get at least 24 hrs out of a charge, but I don't leave either apps open or mobile data constantly on, except for when being used. I do leave wi-fi always on as well as rotate screen, etc. Of course, the more apps & functions I use, the shorter the time the charge lasts.

My only complaint is that the charging cable is cheaply made & two of them, both OEM, have failed. I'm trying a 3rd that appears to be more robustly made from a different manufacturer.

pTitle: ALCATEL OneTouch Idol 3 Global Unlocked 4G LTE Smartphone, 4.7 HD IPS Display, 16GB (GSM - US Warranty)
rText:
Today I am going to be reviewing the Alcatel One Touch Idol 3 and giving my experience being on T-Mobile. I bought this phone honestly not sure what to expect from the call quality since I saw it was only "partial coverage". When I saw that I was like eh I don't call people talk to people through text so eh that's whatever. In regards to the 4G LTE being partial I haven't noticed any problems. I bought this because the size of the screen mainly and also being on a pretty recent Android OS. Right out of the box. As soon as I bought it I was able to update to Android Marshmallow.

Call quality. This is my biggest concern now. I bought this phone expecting the call quality to be good enough and where I could get away with it. Sadly I was was majorly wrong. On T-Mobile people say I am super far away from my phone even though it is right next to my ear and I am talking at a normal level. Now that I am job hunting and getting calls from week to week it has bothered my dad so much that he gave me his old Nokida Windows phone to use when doing phone calls. I was kinda expecting Alcatel to somehow patch or update this phone so that the call quality on T-Mobile would be better but nope.

Size- I have very small hands so 4.7in is amazing. I love being able to use it in its entirety with one hand. That is the main reason why I bought his phone. All the phones now a days are huge for me with their 5.5in screen. I do not like having to do hand gymnastics to swipe down from the top.

*Taken from Obi Wans review since I agree with what he said.* The colors are vibrant. They may be slightly more vibrant than true life colors, but it works. Photos look richer, even if you don't get true life coloring. All the rendered graphics look fantastic due to the rich color depth. (Meaning stuff like your icons and games and the UI interface, etc etc)

Processor/ Ram. The phone lags a bit when playing Love Live Sunshine if I am playing for a while. I did not test any other games.

Storage- 16 gigs is more than enough for me. I installed a SD card encase I ran out of space and wanted to add music onto it.

Photo quality. It takes nice photos. More then what I need for my Instagram. @Nick2D2

Video quality. In sunlight very good. In dark very poor. It does not process low light well at all.

4GLTE Partial Coverage - In regards to the 4G LTE being partial I haven't noticed any problems

With all of that aside. I would recommend this phone if you like to call people instead of texting and are not on T-Mobile.

rText: I purchased 2 of these phone , one for myself and the other a gift. Neither phone is working and it hasnt been a year. I feel real bad for the one i gave as a gift, for now they are looking at me as if I made the phone. Thier phone just kept having issues of turning off and locking up all the time. had to wait days and then it would come back, finally Blu co. replaced that phone, appx. 3 months ago, and now the new phone just died. No display no nothing. Service on their end, say that they didnt carry parts and the phone could not be repaired and its not under warranty. They just sent out the new phone 3 months ago, plus the old phone wasnt even a year old. They sent me a flyer to upgrade my phone at a fee, that I checked out was the same as if purchasing a new phone. Their support is not the best and they definitely dont stand behind their products. They never even asked me to send in the defective phone, said they didnt have parts on a phone they send me 3 months ago, and yes it was a different phone from the one i first purchased. My personal Blu, has a crack in glass, so not sure if I will even try to get that repaired which I must do through their repair department. Dissatified indeed, but when it worked, excellent phone
rTitle: HELP NO SERVICE FOR BLU SUPPORT TEAM

rText: I've had two of these phones and I actually like it a lot. The dual speakers are great. Camera is good, plenty of storage, and it is such a good size. My problem is that with both phones, when I have upgrade from 5.0 to 6.0 software something corrupts the sound and video ability. Videos will play at almost twice the speed if they play at all. And then the amazing speakers will not play any audio for music, podcasts, or videos. But the phone will ring (although it sounds buggy, not normal rings or alarms, they sound... just strange) and you can still talk on the phone with people. So some part of the update corrupts part of the AV of the phone. And from what I can find no one has been able to fix this in any way. SO if you do buy this phone do not upgrade to 6.0 Marshmallow.
rTitle: I've had two of these phones and I actually like it a lot

pTitle: ALCATEL OneTouch Idol 3 Global Unlocked 4G LTE Smartphone, 4.7 HD IPS Display, 16GB (GSM - US Warranty)
rText:
I wanted a phone that had an updated Android OS. I was coming from an Android 2.3, so I was dying for an upgrade. I also needed it to have attractive hardware, decent speakers, be unlocked, and not too big, which is surprisingly hard to find because lots of phones these days are practically tablets. This phone met all my needs and more. My only compliant is the God-awful camera. I knew this before I purchased it. I know that's what had to be sacrificed to sell this phone at such an affordable price. But I really wish there was some way to improve the camera without having to go out and get a bulky add-on lens.

I've had mine for over a year now and I still love it. That's impressive for me because I usually want to replace my new phones less than six months after purchasing it. I did have one problem with it about seven months into owning it where it would automatically shut off, but it was still in warranty so I sent it to the Alcatel tech support and had it back in eight days working as good as new. I think I can still send it to them for additional repairs, but at a fee now, and that is so valuable to me.

If you're looking for an unlocked GSM phone that does the basics, is super light, isn't huge looks good, and comes with a warranty and you're willing to deal with a terrible camera, I'd recommend this phone.
rTitle: Over a year later, and I still love it!

pDescr:
Offer Type:Boost Mobile
The LG Stylo 3 lets you do more than ever before with its large 5.7” HD display and enhanced interactive stylus. Access content quickly and securely using the fingerprint sensor. Its 3,200 mAh battery also lets you talk, text, and browse longer. And a powerful Octa-Core Processor lets you multitask with lightning speed. For use with Boost Mobile service only in the United States. Requires Activation on a Boost Mobile plan for phone use.
pTitle: LG Stylo 3 - Prepaid - Carrier Locked - Boost Mobile
rText:
This phone is perhaps one of the best budget phones I have ever used. I am an artist, and I was looking for a reasonably priced phone with a stylus, so that I could work on digital paintings on the go. I was pleasantly surprised when I found the LG Stylo 3.
Pros: large screen, built in stylus, dou core processor, great cameras, and HD screen.

Cons: low visibility in sunlight, the power and volume buttons are on the back which takes some getting used to. Speaker volume when listening to music is a little low.

Over all this is a great phone, that I am happy to own.

pTitle: LG Stylo 3 - Prepaid - Carrier Locked - Boost Mobile
rText: Anyone who says that the this phone isnt great.....its a lie. this phone as HAS WAY MORE better features than the last two stylos. Ive owned the Stylo 1 and stylo 2 and to now own the new Stylo 3, im super impressed by this phone. The camera is more defined in capturing your photos to the fingerprint scan is the best feature. I do like how the volume buttons are on the side of the phone now which makes it easier. i could write a whole list of why i love this phone so much but i wont but im just say that to anyone who is thinking of getting this phone, you wont be disappointed at all! ;-) Ive been owning alot of LG phones for over the past 3 to 4 yrs and ever since the stylos came out, its been nothing but the BEST with these stylos. If you want a phone that has a big screen to where to can wat h videos and movies on, this phone is for you! :) and of course, Amazon you guys are the best with getting my order out on time & everything! :) I look forward to the day that the LG Stylo 4 is released and i will own that one next!!

pTitle: LG Stylo 3 - Prepaid - Carrier Locked - Boost Mobile
rText:
Seemed like the best phone I could currently get with this carrier, and indeed it is. Any lag isn't noticeable, it can handle multitasking and games pretty well, and all the features work as described (even the stylus!). The phone is kind of big, even for someone with large hands, so it's a little awkward to hold.
Not a phone you should get if rooting is important to you, but for regular everyday users it's better than average.

rText: I liked my Stylo2 and got this after reading reviews. Great phone for the price. Wish there was a little more memory, but that costs money and I'm just not willing to spend $300+ on a phone. I like the easier screenshot, though I find it "easier" when I'm NOT trying to take one than when I am. SO many accidental screenshots and I can't ever get it to work quickly when I actually WANT a screen shot... but I'm sure that's just user error. LOL I never do use the stylus (never did on my Stylo2 either), but it's there and it stays put. Overall, very satisfied with the phone - better than any other phone in this price range.
rTitle: Best phone available in this price bracket!

pTitle: LG Stylo 3 - Prepaid - Carrier Locked - Boost Mobile
rText: I purchased the 2016 LG Stylo 2 and returned it after about a week. I kept running into a problem connecting to the internet, even with 3 bars! I don't know if it was a software issue, but for $40 extra bucks, I have the latest LG Stylo model with only occassional connectivity issues. Possibly those are the Sprint/Virgin Mobile issues since they are affiliated. I can't remember the obvious difference between the two, other than it's Chrome/Google based, and an earlier reviewer (either here or Virgin Mobile website) commented on wanting to use a different ISP. When I have problems, I usually have more difficulty using Firefox than Chrome but I try Firefox first. My only complaint for a 2017 model, is the camera software. Sure, I can go to the App Store and look for a camera app that allows you to do cool moving photo like iPhone, but they all want access to my phone (why, I ask, should an app be given permission to view my email or any other phone app and file just so I can take a picture with your app?). Why isn't this app pre-loaded with LG software (that has 3-4 second moving photo)? Someone is out there thinking, 'you already give permission for a lot of that software to have that access to your phone', I try to deny it when I can. That's my primary pet-peeve.
rTitle: No complaints so far for a 2017 model

rText: Over all the LG Stylo 3 is a ok phone. Why it gets a 3 star rating from me is for 2 reasons. One, you can not remove certain apps from the home screen. You can only mobe them into groups or other screens or pages that are not the home screen. Two, and this is the biggest reason for me, you have no control over the camera settings unlike on other budget phones I've owned such as the Samsung Galaxy Grand Prime. When you take a photo of say a landscape or sunrise/set it blows the sky out and leaves you with just a nasty looking photo. LG dropped the ball here. Hope they fix it if they update thus model.

pTitle: Sony Xperia L1 - Unlocked Smartphone - 16GB - Black (US Warranty)
rText:
I purchased this as an upgrade to a Moto G4 Play which was running LineageOS 14.1 (AOSP 7.1.2 Nougat). I needed a phone with a more reliable GPS, and the NFC option (for things like Android Pay) greatly enticed me (though I've yet to really try it out just yet). After having the phone a few days, here are my thoughts:

+ The Xperia L1's GPS includes GLONASS (Russian satellite support), something the entire Moto G series desperately needed. Satellite lock is almost instant and very accurate. The L1 also has a magnetometer (digital compass) which was absent in the Moto G series.
+ The Xperia L1's screen, while lower pixel density (267ppi vs 294 on the G4 Play), has much better color saturation. The screen is also half an inch larger, ideal for using Nougat's multi-window mode.
= The L1's 13MP camera is about on par with the Moto G4 Play's 8MP camera when using auto-focus. However, the manual shot mode on the L1 does appear to have a decent array of options which might give it a competitive edge in the hands of an experienced photographer.
= The Xperia L1 comes with Android 7.0 out of the box, while the G4 Play claims it will update to 7.1.1 through standard OTA. Motorola has had numerous delays in deploying this update, hence the initial need to use a custom ROM. There aren't too many differences, honestly, and the L1 is already getting a steady stream of support updates, making them evenly matched in software.
= Bluetooth problems seem to be inherent on all Nougat devices right now, including Google's own flagship Pixel devices. The G4 Play running Lineage 14.1 will often disconnect from Bluetooth when connecting/disconnecting a Wi-Fi network, and phone calls on Bluetooth can occasionally force a reboot. Meanwhile, on the Xperia L1, the connection is stable but much shorter. Audio becomes finicky as far away as 5 meters on a device with a max range of 30 meters.
= The L1's USB-C connector is still using the 2.0 standard, giving it roughly the same data transfer and charge rates as the G4 Play's MicroUSB port. However, the Type-C port feels a lot sturdier than the old MicroUSB port, which justifies the necessity of newer (better) cables.
- The L1's MediaTek 6737T, despite having better benchmarks than the G4 Play's Snapdragon 410, has considerably more lag. This was a major disappointment for me as someone who uses their phone for EVERYTHING. Apps take a bit longer to open, and the keyboard has a slightly poorer response rate.
- The L1 has a glass screen with a hardness of 6. However, it's so thick that if you try and place a tempered glass screen protector on top of it, the touch screen struggles to register much of anything. This means you need to go without and be a lot more careful than you would need to be with the G4 Play, which happily accepts tempered glass screen protectors.

Is the Xperia L1 worth $200? I would say it's worth close enough to $200 not to matter. It more than makes up for the limitations of the Moto G4 Play, though it would have done better with a processor to match. It can beat out some phones in its class (like the Nokia 3), but other phones (like the upcoming Moto E4) might give it a run for its money (provided Motorola does not make the same mistakes twice).
rTitle: Worthwhile if upgrading from an inferior model, but do your research.

pTitle: Sony Xperia L1 - Unlocked Smartphone - 16GB - Black (US Warranty)
rText:
I own the Xperia X, an excellent phone by Sony. I always thought the Xperia X could be iPhone 6 plus killer, everything is better on that phone compare to the iPhone. Camera (far superior with 23 MP rear), size and resolution. It is also less expensive than this phone, I paid $175 for it when it was on sale on Amazon.

In all respects, the Xperia L1 is a much lesser phone, but yet costs more. Cameras has less resolutions (13MP vs. 23MP) and feels plastic cheap in the hand. About the only thing that is better is the L1 uses USB-C for connection and charging, which is a better technology than micro USB. But that also presents a problem: you can find micro USB cable anywhere, but USB-C is a bit hard to come by. L1 also has less on-board memory, only 16GB instead of 32GB.

Android is also much more exciting than iOS, the radio app alone should be a key consideration. Something the iPhone world could only dream off. I took some pictures with the Sony X and they are phenomenal. If you need a phone now, Sony XPeria is a very good choice.

So I think if you are considering getting a Sony Xperia, look at the X. Its a much better phone and costs less.
rTitle: Nice phone but there are better Sony Xperia options.

pTitle: Sony Xperia L1 - Unlocked Smartphone - 16GB - Black (US Warranty)
rText:
Great phone! My first Sony smartphone ever. I changed to Sony from iPhone followed Samsung. Really disappointed by the exterior design of Apple since Steve Jobs' death, or the terribly tuned Android System in the Galaxy S7. This L1 is so great that it makes me writing this long review, also my first review for online shopping. Sony's software engineers did great work making that Android System so comfortable and very user-friendly.

This L1 is cheaper than the other two phones, but it feels faster than my Galaxy S7, which has a lot better hardwares even is made 1yr before. There is no glitch or crash, and everything is so smooth to run.

I can only give 4 stars because of the camera. After all, it's an affordable smartphone, I don't expect too much. However, the camera is the only slow thing on this phone. It can took up to 5sec to open it. Also, it doesn't come with any good features like shacking-proof.

pTitle: Sony Xperia L1 - Unlocked Smartphone - 16GB - Black (US Warranty)
rText:
This is our second Sony phone(other is last years xperia x, which I am a fan of other than battery life), I have the white version of this phone. the case is plastic and pearlized (gives a pinkish glow when light refracts off it giving it a femine feel.) The phone is as big as the xperia x in a case (little bigger than I like but wife thinks its fine and the rounded back helps, the plus of this is the screen seems a lot bigger. Where the x has rounded corners and rounded front glass the L1 the front is flat making the front corners more square and have a sharper feeling (could be negated with case). The phone is easy to set up and responds well (signalwise in a rural Ohio with ATT) you may want to check what bands are available in your area, some of the other models support more (when setting up the phone in store took a little as they don't see many Sony phones and are unfamiliar and curious) It is fine for your internet browsing, you tube videos, calls, texts, etc. the lower ram does hurt it's performance if you are trying to watch movies on this. This phone also does not support fast charging if you are use to that it will seem like a step back. One thing Sony does that a lot of other companies do not do, is it has the FM radio unlocked, plug in headphones and you can listen to the radio (is not as big of drain on battery nor does it use data to listen unlike streaming, a nice plus) I would recommend this phone for people on a budget or looking for a basic phone and something different.

Side note and may not represent all experiences The phone was dropped twice by accident (cringed both times) once in the driveway gravel face down no scratches, and once waist high on back on concrete neither cracked the screen but I would recommend a case for this phone
rTitle: A phone for for people looking for something different, basic, or on a budget

pTitle: Sony Xperia L1 - Unlocked Smartphone - 16GB - Black (US Warranty)
rText:
The phone is quite basic. It does have nice display, and the touch works well. Sound is OK. But this thing loses wifi signal and needs to be rebooted to connect again - shows authentication problem. It is not the signal strength - my other phone works perfectly right next to this one with no problems at all.
The sound quality is not too good. I can hear the other side, but sometimes not very clear. Watching videos is a pain because of the poor sound.
The phone is basic, so it lacks many features my Samsung S6 has. It does not have sensors to enable it to play many of the games and use it for 3D viewing (google Cardboard does not work due to lack of sensors). It has geomagnetic field, accelerometer, light and proximity sensors. There is no fingerprint sensor or heart and O2 sensors. It is noticeably slower. And screen resolution is way lower. I liked that there is much less software installed on the phone compared with Samsung.
rTitle: looses wifi signal and has to be rebooted to connect again

pTitle: Sony Xperia L1 - Unlocked Smartphone - 16GB - Black (US Warranty)
rText:
For the price, I'm hard-pressed to think of a better phone that you can buy new.

Is it as nice as my Xperia XZ? No. But it's still awfully nice.

Sony's design language is a love-it-or-hate-it kind of thing. Personally, I adore it. The L1 is reminiscent of my last Clie PDA, thrust into the future. Build quality is excellent for this price range, and quite good relative to more expensive phones. There were no creaks or gaps to speak of, and the display is clear and bright.

Their implementation of Android is not only current, but very thoughtfully left alone, for the most part. It isn't quite stock Android, but the UI very rarely gets in the way of letting you do things. Coming from an XZ, the slower CPU isn't too apparent in normal productivity use, but there is a substantial difference when you get into games and other apps that are more resource intensive.

While I'd normally complain about the tiny 16GB storage, the addition of a MicroSD slot (which aren't present on some flagship phones, let alone one in this range) is excellent. Dropping a 200GB SanDisk card full of media gave me hours to put this phone through its paces.

So, would I buy one? If money was a constraint, absolutely. I'm not giving up my XZ for it (and may still pick up the new XZ Premium), but as a replacement for a device that's two years old, or a first Android device, it's an outstanding choice.
rTitle: I can't believe it's so cheap!

pTitle: Sony Xperia L1 - Unlocked Smartphone - 16GB - Black (US Warranty)
rText:
Great phone. I can't understand the few low reviews - not sure they are real. Sad. There is absolutely No bloatware on this phone. It is an unlocked...$200 dollar phone. Every app nearly every app is removable. I have had carrier Samsung phones crazy apps you cant use like GPS apps you pay for monthly to AT&T - crap no one uses. This phone has none of that. So refreshing. Other criticisms I see here "phone is heavy" and "build quality". Again, those things do not make sense. This phone feels every bit as well-built as my previous Samsung S7 Edge. (plus it cost less than just trying to fix my S7s cracked screen). The phone feelings awesome- it has some weight but it feels built like a tank.

I could not recommend this phone more. Cheaper than a repair to your cracked "premium" phone - I feel like this phone is an absolute home run. Only downsides, no finger print scanner, and not lightning fast (but not at all sluggish). I am done buying the latest feature phone - this phone is that good.
rTitle: Revolution: great phone cheaper than a screen repair to most "cool phones“. Love it.

pTitle: Sony Xperia L1 - Unlocked Smartphone - 16GB - Black (US Warranty)
rText:
I have used Sony Xperia smartphones exclusively for over four years including the Z ultra, Z3, T2 Ultra, Z1 compact and now the L1. All of them were excellent but this is my favorite so far. I did not order this phone from Amazon, I bought it at a retail store because my most recent smartphone was misplaced and I needed a replacement immediately.

I generally do not run any background apps and always close them when not in use. I have noticed some minor bugs with all of them except this phone including some difficulty connecting to wifi networks when not in close proximity. They tend to show 3 or 4 bars of signal when detected but when I select "connect" it drops to one little dot and fails to connect. This will generally happen repeatedly until I either give up or move to better range of the router and it has been something I have learned to get used to but this doesn't occur with the L1. I think it has something to do with the new Mediatek processor.

I was always irked by the need to pair with my bluetooth headset anew on my MacBook Pro every time I had paired it to my previous Xperia models which I thought was caused by Apple unpairing from it, but I do not have that problem with this phone. It seemed a strange bug, and I just got used to it. Now I can switch back and forth from my devices with my bluetooth headset very quickly and smoothly.

I don't see the small apps when I tap the square and I don't miss them, now the square seems to only bring up background running apps so I can close them and save battery and performance. To me this is a welcome change. In all other ways it is the same old Sony user interface, simple, Spartan and neat. It has been the UI that has kept Sony Smartphones in my pocket for so long as my dependable tool in every situation.

The display isn't 4k. It doesn't seem to me to be necessary to have an extremely high definition display for a handheld device, even for consuming entertainment media. It just eats through the battery and costs a lot. The display is still quite nice and in fact, I have noticed another improvement over my previous Xperia phones. When I select the dimmest back lighting with the slider it is much dimmer than with those previous models. It always seemed to me to still be more than adequately bright on the dimmest setting before and I had wondered if I could extend the battery life yet more by having it dimmer. Now I can. The touch sensitivity seems to me as responsive as any previous Xperia model.

Very pocketable 5.5 inches. I have had a couple of phones which were excessively thin and have wondered if an extra couple of milimeters of thickness would be OK if it meant a slightly bigger battery. Well the battery is still only 2620 MaH. However with the toned down specs, smooth performance and average display it still seems to last as well as previous models if not better (excluding the T2 ultra which was just a beast). With the near lack of a bezel it is the perfect size for me as the T2 ultra was just too big.

Excellent build quality. The matte black version feels great in my hand and at this price point for an unlocked phone I suspect that negative reviews are paid for by competitors. It feels like a very high quality device and not at all cheap feeling like a Samsung phone. It is elegant and yet durable. For $200 US, this phone is peerless.

The camera is only adequate. This may be the most important detail for me. I am a photographer and I travel with several cameras and lenses, including some highly portable combinations so I simply have no need for an overblown and expensive smartphone camera. If I need to snap a quick shot of something, it is fine and has a flash in case lighting is insufficient for a shot. For those of you who need an incredible camera on your smartphone, I will try to keep my disdain to myself and suggest one of the models designed for selfies for your instagram but this model will achieve decent shots if you need it to.
rTitle: Quality can be had affordably with a well considered design.

pTitle: Sony Xperia L1 - Unlocked Smartphone - 16GB - Black (US Warranty)
rText:
I am using this as an international cell phone, picking up cheap SIMs overseas, and using this for China travel rather than my typical iPhone. The screen quality is very nice, though the rest of the device feels somewhat plasticky. Voice call quality is not terribly good for some reason, though audio through the headphones is fine. There is a good deal of junk installed on the phone as it arrives and some of it can't be deleted (or I couldn't trivially delete it anyway). Software updates and signing up for this and that on the device took an hour or so. Still, this is an inexpensive smartphone with no commitments. You will almost certainly want to add a micro SD card for additional storage. Will update after some additional foreign travel (Japan and Korea up next).

The simple box included the phone, charger, cable, and a couple of quick start pieces of paper. A sticker on the back of the phone indicates which orientation you should insert the SIM and SD cards.
rTitle: Cost cutting is evident, but fundamentally decent

pTitle: Sony Xperia L1 - Unlocked Smartphone - 16GB - Black (US Warranty)
rText:
A beautiful phone for a really low price. My favorite phone of ALL time was the Sony Xperia Z3 compact, and I've had samsungs, iphones, google nexus, etc. This one hasn't let me down so far.
There are some minor problems which was expected:
-- Can't run multiple programs, can be slow at times, so I try to close out programs as often as possible.
-- Battery life has been pretty good, but during extended use-time or while it's charging, the top half of the phone gets hot.
-- Heavy and larger than what I like, but I'm used to it by now.
-- I've had a few people tell me to speak up in call. So I believe the mic quality is not the best.
-- (Also phone sound quality is terrible, so I use headphones).
-- Internet (4G LTE) doesn't' work while in a call.
-- Does not have stereo speakers.

rText: Poor build quality, Heavy for having a super small battery, Battery life poor - gets about 3 to 4 hrs max usage before it drops to less than 25%. Tons of bloatware that cannot be uninstalled. Once you load apps up your down to only 2 to 2.5gb free. Sony software is proprietary and it does the software shuffling between sd card and internal for you which is a big mess - half the time it only moves the extremely small apps and leave the larger one on the internal. If you load a different launcher the notifications for phone calls, emails and text's never come across. Performance is pitiful. I have a cheapy Blu phone that i will put up against the Sony and it would win... that is pretty bad..

pTitle: Moto G (4th Gen.) Unlocked - White - 16GB
rText: When I got this a few months ago, for the great specs, I assumed the ghost touches, or ghost thumping, or screen tap dancing - or whatever you call it - was a software glitch that would be fixed by an update. No such luck. The phone repeatedly dialed on its own, and of course always the person I didnt want to bother. It "freaked out" during important calls and opened every imagiable screen. And, all of the other problems you can read about in other reviews. While waiting for the software update that never came, too much time went by to return it. Tonight I got the idea it might be my glass screen protector causing interference, so I tried to remove it. The protector wouldnt come off easily, and in the process of asserting some muscle to it the screen crumbled. So, after less than a year I am throwing it away. I never did find anything so Prime "exclusive" about it that I couldn't have done the same thing on any other phone by adding the easily available Amazon apps. A frustrating experience and waste of good money.

You've been warned!!

pTitle: Moto G (4th Gen.) Unlocked - White - 16GB
rText: I like the phone when it's working correctly. However, after having it just ten months, several times a day it freezes and will not let me do anything. Every couple of days it spontaneously restarts itself. About once a week I have to do a hard reset, and it stops recognizing my SD card until it has been turned off. Sometimes it takes multiple reboots. About once a week it becomes incredibly hot, almost hot enough to burn me. Apps regularly crash. It doesn't have any malware or viruses. I've checked. These are all issues with this phone itself. There are more, but that's a good beginning...

rText:
This seemed like a great phone at first - not too much bloatware, beautiful display, awesome battery life, etc. etc.

Less than six months after purchase, it stopped recognizing my sim card. No error message, just a message that no sim card was detected. After hours spent on the phone with my carrier and Lenovo, I sent it back for replacement under warranty. I just received my replacement today and it worked for about twenty minutes before it too stopped recognizing my sim card. Based on my reading the Lenovo forums, this is a super common issue with this phone and there's no sign of a solution.
rTitle: This seemed like a great phone at first - not too much ...

rText: We find that the LG G4 is prone to unexpected failures. It's as if the phones short themselves out. The average lasts about six months after purchase and dies. LG replaces phones within one year but I would say they are highly unreliable.
rTitle: Three LG G4 phones have failed in 15 months

pDescr:
Color:Gray
It’s easy to love the LG G4 based on looks alone, but much of its innovation lies beneath the surface.
pTitle: LG G4 H810 Metallic Grey GSM Unlocked Android 4G LTE 32GB Smartphone
rText:
Guys, first of all, this is not H811 but H810 AT&T "unlocked" phone, i bought during my vacation in the US, i came back to my country and it seemed to work well, but it didn't last 1 month to show a big issue, security menu was damaged with this message: " Com.security.android" has been stoppped, making the phone totally unable to uninstall or even set a password, i researched a lot about this phone (i am an IT guy so, im familiar with trouble shooting), and just found out AT&T blocked most of the features used to root or re install firmware into it. if its not good enough, my SIM card started failing so i decided to my carrier store and changed it, biggest error, it turns out that AT&T just blocked the IMEI and now it is just a useless brick. dont even take the risk if you live in the US this phone (or this version) doesnt worth your money.

Its the first time in 6 years i rate a product so low.
rTitle: if its not good enough, my SIM card started failing so i ...

pTitle: Smart Phone Repair Tool Kit (17-Piece)
rText: The screwdriver is a high quality anodized aluminum with rubber o-ring grips and a rotating palm pad. There is a nice plastic pry tool with a sharp finger to grap hold. The bit holder swings up to expose the bits, which is classy touch for such a low priced kit. The standalone magnifier is clutch for hands free operation, and the suction cup is handy to remove screens. All in all, I think this is actually a really nice little tool kit for basically just a few bucks. I definitely recommend it!

pTitle: Smart Phone Pouch, Black
rText: The TB-33 is a very cleverly designed holder for your cell phone . A great addition to construction workers who need to keep a pencil and pad of paper handy for notes. Each pouch comes with a spiral pad and carpenters pencil . I was worried when i fist got it that my phone wold not fit as it looked small. but when i slid my Galaxy 7 edge into the pouch it slid in easily and fit fine. The pouch has a metal clip on the back that you can clip onto your belt. It also had a loop on the side that i assume you could use for an ink pen that has a clasp to hold it to the loop.and there is a small D ring carabiner that could possibly hold keys. The plastic cover over the locking clip is very hard to remove to open the clip. so clip on keys might work better .

pTitle: Smart Phone Pouch, Black
rText: This is a great idea to protect an expensive cell phone from potential damage while on the job site. This cell phone pouch is made from tough polyester with edging that is double stitched. The pouch that holds the cell phone is lined with a smooth material that will resist scratching the cell phone screen. However, since the pouch does not completely enclose the cell phone it is still subject to dust, dirt, sawdust, etc. which could eventually cause scratches to the screen. My cell phone measures 3" wide by 5 3/4" long and was a snug fit. The pouch includes a small notebook, 2" X 4", with approximately 50 sheets of gridded paper and a small flat style pencil. See Photo 1 and 2. The only negative I had was the belt clip. The clip is a flat piece of spring metal that was difficult to put on over a belt and more difficult to get off. I had to unfasten my belt to get it off. The belt clip used by this company on its other tool pouches is much better.

rText: You go to a phone store of your phone service provder(Verizon) that sold you the phone to find a good phone case only to find they don't have one for your phone, or they cary cheap universals that are glued together and don't last two months. The last phone case I bought from Home Depot was a canvas case made by Husky and lasted me a year and six months. When I went looking for the same phone case, I discovered Husky had discontinued it. Having discovered the ToughBuilt I decided to purchase and love it. It is a very durable case and meets my needs as a charter bus driver for carrying items for maintaining a drivers log book. I know this phone case will last and I would purchase another.

pTitle: Smart Phone Pouch, Black
rText:
This is a well built phone pouch with well thought out design. My Android phone was snug in the pouch. In fact it was a bit difficult to pull the phone back out until I figured out that I can nudge it up from the bottom of the pouch.
The pouch protects the phone very well from bumps or hits however it does not provide much protection to the phone from dusty environments such as sheetrock work or saw dust.
The Velcroed enclosure flap holds the phone and note pad in securely without too much fear of the flap lifting unintentionally.
The design of the case was well thought out with pouches and loops. The loops could hold small hand tools such as small screwdrivers with pocket clip. The note pad and pouch is a nice idea but as stated before, not ideal in dusty conditions. The pouch size is adequate. There is room for the average sized smart phone although I do not believe it would hold something like the Samsung Note.

pTitle: AT&T Alcatel Ideal GoPhone Prepaid Smartphone
rText: Bought this phone for my 10 year old daughter for her birthday in August, it is her first phone. She only had 3 pics, 5 apps and a handful of contacts and the phone would constantly remind her that the storage space was running low, it says on the box you get up to 8GB of memory but you actually only get 4GB because of all the junk they have using up the memory and  you couldn't shut the reminder off, when she would try to go on any of her apps it wouldn't even let her on anything even though the space wasnt completely used up it was only running low, and then it froze up, i had to take it to an Att&T store to have it reset because i didn't know how to do it, and buying a SD card is only good if you want more pics on your phone, its no good for apps. So after the reset she could only put like 3 apps back onto the phone. Also I noticed in another review someone had problems answering phone calls,  we had that problem as well. When someone was calling you could tap, swipe, whatever and you could not answer the dang incoming call!! how frustrating!! So yea this phone isnt even good for a 10 year old!! BEWARE!!!

pTitle: AT&T Alcatel Ideal GoPhone Prepaid Smartphone
rText: I have owned this same phone now for many years. Its a great phone. As anyone would expect it does get a bit sluggish once it is filled with apps, and if you have multiple windows open, and multiple apps running. Thankfully this is easily solved by pressing the square button and selecting close all. After that it speeds up again. For 30 bucks you cant really beat this. The camera is pretty mediocre, but did a fine job when I went on a road trip without a good camera, even with photos of scenic mountains. I would definitely recommend for anyone looking for a basic phone. If youre someone who finds they are always breaking or dropping phones this is a great option. For 5 dollars they offer a plan that will replace it no matter what. Great deal!

pTitle: AT&T Samsung Galaxy Express 3 GoPhone
rText: Over all not a terrible phone, good carrier, and descent specs. The problem is massive amounts of Bloatware between AT&T and Samsung. That would be fine if Samsung would have made or updated it with the internal fully mounted sd card option. If you like to use more than a few apps on your Android device this is not the phone for you because of space limited by bloated OS and loaded apps. Also the signal strength on this phone is not bad but it's not great either and it lacks some functionality like the ability to create some commonly expected shortcuts. If you only need a cheap phone and only need a few apps it's still a great phone for the price.

pTitle: AT&T Samsung Galaxy Express 3 GoPhone
rText:
do not, and i repeat do not buy this phone if you want lots of storage space and if you use lots of apps. i downloaded only 3 apps and have almost zero storage, despite having all my pics, videos and music stored on my sd card. this phone i would say is suitable for someone who uses very little internet, and only needs a phone for talk and text.
i will keep this phone a year or so then i will trade up. i had the gophone windows nokia lumia and it had tons more storage on it, i had numerous apps. i only traded because fb messenger app is no longer available to windows phone. so i got this express 3 about 3 weeks ago and i have already had to unmount my sd card and remove all my pics and delete some music in order not to run out of space, no room on this phone for games or much media. i am very disappointed. do your research and if you are going with a gophone find one with more storage. also, my onedrive is very slow to upload, i went to a concert and had to wait almost 14 hours before all my photos and videos uploaded to one drive, then i had to share them, save them to my pc and delete as i was getting low storage warnings. this is def not the phone for anyone who likes taking videos/pics.

pTitle: AT&T Samsung Galaxy Express 3 GoPhone
rText: My Samsung Galaxy S3 mini finally crapped out, did not want to pay $300 to AT&T for a new phone.  I just use the phone to talk, text and stream IHeart radio.  This phone works great for that.  I do take pics every now and then.  The 5 mega pixel camera takes good enough pics for me.  The battery last at least two days with average usage.  The S3 mini had to be charged every night.  With only 8 gig memory though, there is not alot of room left on the phone, but it does have a slot for a memory card which is where the pics automatically load to so it is not an issue for me.  If you need more memory, go with the Samsung Galaxy Express Prime, it comes with 16 gig and a 5 inch screen, I just did not want that large of a phone.  I really like the 4.5 screen on the Express 3.  The lack of memory is the only reason for 4 stars instead of 5.

pTitle: AT&T Samsung Galaxy Express 3 GoPhone
rText: My current phone got dropped and the screen cracked causing it to be virtually unusable. The repair would be costly and time consuming. I had to have a quick back up phone for calls, etc. This fits the bill. It's nothing fancy... it's a $50 go phone. It does have bloatware, but most of it can be disabled by going into "app info". You have to look at the specs and you know what you are going to get - but for something as a backup so you have a phone, this is well worth the money. All I did was put my current micro-sim card in the slot and I was back up and running. When I'm done using the phone, it will be my daughter's phone to start her out.

rText:
My iPhone wouldn't charge but i couldn't get it fixed for a week, and I needed a phone in the mean time for work and such. I ran to Wal-Mart at 9pm and grabbed this puppy. It's no iPhone, of course, but it gets the basics done. I can text my family and check my work email. The battery lasted all day, through much web surfing. 

I would recommend this as a backup phone, or as a starter or budget smart phone. If I had a kid that was begging for a smart phone, this is the one I'd get. It's definitely worth the price.

pTitle: AT&T Samsung Galaxy Express 3 GoPhone
rText:
Really good phone for the money.  Really good.  As of now, I am listening to songs ported through the phone's headset jack to the Aux port on my car stereo.  The phone's advanced sound options do more harm than good, for me, so I am happiest with those features dis-abled.  The phone acts like a high end model but with less sensors.  No compass app will work but you'll never be lost...this phone has GPS and turn-by-turn direction apps, namely AT&T Navigator and Google Maps.  The phone has enough memory for essential apps only, so plan on spending $20 for a fast micro SD memory card.  An example, the SanDisk 32 Meg extreme U3, currently selling for $18.  If card is not fast enough..... phone will reject it.
Battery is good and you can replace it yourself without the need for the cost of a tedious phone repair expense.  Phone operates on current Marshmallow operating system which is peppy and will run your favorite games and banking apps.  Keep in mind purchasing the $20 micro SD memory card with it.  I wish I had.  Good WiFi and calls sound good.  Visual voicemail app does not work so I use Google Voicemail app and it works.  Otherwise, press and hold the 1 key to access your voicemail....easy peasy.
Windows users... Cortana app works great on this phone and you can activate her by pressing and holding the Menu key.  Office apps such as Word available.  Some cool looking glass launcher themes are available for transparent, glass-like buttons.  If you still miss live tiles on Windows phone, you can add widgets to this phone so reallly...you can call in love with a non-Windows phone that Will sync with your PC.  Colors on this display are so beautiful they seem to glow.  My sensors are pleased as is my mind with this GALAXY EXPRESS 3 AT&T GOPHONE.
THANK YOU!

The only down side is that it only has 8gb of storage so you really cant download many apps, but it wasn't a really big problem since my tablet runs off of the same network. So if you're looking for a phone to hold you over without spending a fortune to get it, this is definitely a good buy.

pTitle: AT&T Samsung Galaxy Express 3 GoPhone
rText: I'm not a tech whiz by any means, but i have some inherent smarts. If you know how to disable and/or delete all of the bloatware and preinstalled apps you clear up a ton of space, making this a good phone for the low price. I was hesitant, for sure, but this little guy has eased my worries. I run my basic media apps (Facebook, Instagram, Twitter) and still have room for other goodies like games and mobile banking. I definitely recommend this phone if you don't require a small computer in your pocket all day, but rather a decent quality phone that keeps you in touch with the world.

pTitle: AT&T Samsung Galaxy Express 3 GoPhone
rText:
I've had this phone for 3 months now (Since feb 2017). I bought it thinking, hey, this is a samsung...must be good right? Well, it was for the first couple weeks...then it became slow and unresponsive at times. The Phone itself isn't bad, the body design is light and small enough to fit in your pocket without feeling like you're carrying a brick, (I'd advise a case, as the phone feels like a feather might break it). But then comes the internal design...the fun part. The processor starts out good, but after a couple weeks...well it's like the phone's running on XP, it slows down. If you're using the phone for texting and calling, it'll work just fine, but if you're looking for something to play games on or video chat...keep walking this phone is NOT for you. The camera is sub par quality, the speakers are not very loud, even with a volume booster it's hard to hear most music/videos. The text's can be responsive at times,but if you let the screen sleep and have the text open, you'll need to reopen the screen to see if you have a new one...as it won't notify you. The music volume on their...is well, decent if you have good headphones, but that's really it. If you're looking for a phone that can run pokemon go, keep moving you'll load then never move. I've also had to do about 2-3 factory resets on the phone and mind you I've got a anti-virus,cleaners and defraggers on there. STILL runs slow. If you're looking for a decent cheap phone, go for the LG Phoenix 2, it has better specs and will probably last longer.

Pros-Cheap,stylish,smooth case
Cons-Slow after short usage,cheap processor,overheats,low volume

out of ten I give it 3.5 stars.

THE ONLY PROBLEM IS THAT YOU CAN NOT HEAR THE OTHER PARTY WHEN YOU ARE ON A PHONE CALL.  No matter how loud the volume is up you and not hear the other person clearly.  You will have to use the speaker mode or the ear piece.
No privacy!!

As some of the other posts have said, it comes with a bunch of pre installed apps that nearly fill up the 8 gig memory which is VERY annoying.  Besides the low memory of only 8 gigs phone is great, however I would recommend using a Bluetooth with it, when i first got it people couldn't hear me at all (speaker is on bottom of phone) which I realized later on.  Over all this is a good phone for the money good battery life and nice features.

rText: This phone is actually a good deal for the money I paid for it. It has pre installed apps that isn't removable which a sd card seems to help.  There isn't any type of case made for it that actually fits it properly and the screen is easily cracked, I was playing a drum simulator app on it and wasn't tapping on the screen where mine is cracked, and being a phone and not an actual drum set I wasn't tapping hard and the screen cracked. With that said and all, the phone ,screen and battery all still work. Also the carrier at&t is a good service and have excellent plan options and helpful customer service and easy to use apps pertaining to at&t only. I'd recommend the phone to both friends and enemies.

pDescr:
Now you can have a phone with an easy-to-see screen and crisp, clear sound, thanks to the AT&T Huawei Ascend XT GoPhone Prepaid Smartphone. The HD display of this cellular accessory offers a bright, vivid viewing experience. The android smartphone is wonderful for browsing and making statements via social media. The smart design offers a large screen without being bulky, and its narrow body makes the Ascend XT easy to hold. This AT&T smartphone contains 2GB of RAM and 16GB of internal memory. It has a microSD card slot (card sold separately) that supports up to 32GB. This makes your memory easier to expand. You get up to 17 hours of talk time, giving you plenty of hours to make calls to friends and family. And you can take nice photos with an 8MP rear-facing camera. Have a phone with plenty of useful features when you own the AT&T Huawei Ascend XT GoPhone Prepaid Smartphone.

6" touchscreen

3000mAh battery

pTitle: AT&T Huawei Ascend XT GoPhone Prepaid Smartphone
rText: Huawei and At&t crippled the software on this phone with their customizations, skins, themes, and bloatware which can not be uninstalled, or disabled except for like 3 or 4 apps. The phone is super buggy because of it. Sometimes the phone randomly deletes my text messages, other times the it becomes unresponsive for a few seconds. I have to restart it at least once a week to get performance back. There have been a few software updates according to At&t's support site but I CAN NOT GET THEM because the phone refuses to check for updates. I found a way to apply the updates manually and while it seemed like it worked my wifi is completely disabled now as a result of it (see pic). I'm no amateur, I've been jailbreaking, unlocking, rooting for years. I've never seen manufacturer and carrier bloat as bad as it is on the Huawei Ascend XT which is a shame because the construction, cpu, and overall hardware is solid.
